section_id: ## 3. Proof that Fractal Set Satisfies Causal Set Axioms

hints.label: def-fractal-set-causal-order
hints.title: Causal Order on Fractal Set
hints.content:
146: :label: def-fractal-set-causal-order
147: 
148: For episodes $e_i, e_j \in E$ with positions $x_i, x_j \in \mathcal{X}$ and times $t_i, t_j \in \mathbb{R}$, define:
149: 
150: $$
151: e_i \prec_{\text{CST}} e_j \quad \iff \quad t_i < t_j \text{ and } d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_i, x_j) < c(t_j - t_i)
152: $$
153: 
154: where:
155: - $d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_i, x_j)$ is the **Riemannian distance** on $(\mathcal{X}, g)$
156: - $c$ is the effective "speed of light" (maximal information propagation speed)

hints.label: rem-lorentzian-from-riemannian
hints.title: Relation to Lorentzian Structure
hints.content:
162: :label: rem-lorentzian-from-riemannian
163: 
164: The emergent Riemannian metric $g(x)$ on $\mathcal{X}$ can be promoted to a Lorentzian metric on spacetime $M = \mathbb{R} \times \mathcal{X}$ by:
165: 
166: $$
167: ds^2 = -c^2 dt^2 + g_{ij}(x) dx^i dx^j
168: $$
169: 
170: The causal order $\prec_{\text{CST}}$ then corresponds to the **chronological order** induced by this Lorentzian metric:
171: 
172: $$
173: e_i \prec e_j \quad \iff \quad x_j \in J^+(x_i)
174: $$

hints.raw_directive:
179: ### 3.2. Verification of Causal Set Axioms
180: 
181: :::{prf:theorem} Fractal Set is a Valid Causal Set
182: :label: thm-fractal-set-is-causal-set
183:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-45
hints.content:
186: 
187: :::{prf:proof}
188: We verify each axiom:
189: 
190: **Axiom CS1 (Irreflexivity): $e \not\prec e$ for all $e \in E$**
191: 
192: For any episode $e_i$ with time $t_i$:
193: 
194: $$
195: e_i \prec_{\text{CST}} e_i \quad \iff \quad t_i < t_i \text{ and } d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_i, x_i) < c(t_i - t_i)
196: $$
197: 
198: $$
199: \iff \quad t_i < t_i \text{ and } 0 < 0
200: $$
201: 
202: Both conditions are false, so $e_i \not\prec_{\text{CST}} e_i$. ✓
203: 
204: **Axiom CS2 (Transitivity): $e_1 \prec e_2$ and $e_2 \prec e_3$ implies $e_1 \prec e_3$**
205: 
206: Assume $e_1 \prec_{\text{CST}} e_2$ and $e_2 \prec_{\text{CST}} e_3$. Then:
207: 
208: 1. $t_1 < t_2 < t_3$ (time ordering is transitive)
209: 2. $d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x_2) < c(t_2 - t_1)$
210: 3. $d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_2, x_3) < c(t_3 - t_2)$
211: 
212: By the **triangle inequality** for Riemannian distance:
213: 
214: $$
215: d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x_3) \leq d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x_2) + d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_2, x_3)
216: $$
217: 
218: $$
219: < c(t_2 - t_1) + c(t_3 - t_2) = c(t_3 - t_1)
220: $$
221: 
222: Therefore $t_1 < t_3$ and $d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x_3) < c(t_3 - t_1)$, which means $e_1 \prec_{\text{CST}} e_3$. ✓
223: 
224: **Axiom CS3 (Local Finiteness): $|\{e \in E : e_1 \prec e \prec e_2\}| < \infty$**
225: 
226: The set $I(e_1, e_2) := \{e \in E : e_1 \prec e \prec e_2\}$ is the **causal interval** between $e_1$ and $e_2$.
227: 
228: **Geometric characterization**: An episode $e$ is in $I(e_1, e_2)$ iff:
229: 
230: $$
231: t_1 < t < t_2 \quad \text{and} \quad d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x) < c(t - t_1) \quad \text{and} \quad d_{\mathcal{X}}(x, x_2) < c(t_2 - t)
232: $$
233: 
234: This defines a **bounded region** $\mathcal{D} \subset \mathbb{R} \times \mathcal{X}$ (a "double cone" in spacetime).
235: 
236: **Expected number of episodes in $\mathcal{D}$**:
237: 
238: $$
239: \mathbb{E}[|I(e_1, e_2)|] = \int_{\mathcal{D}} \rho_{\text{episode}}(t, x) \, dt \, dx
240: $$
241: 
242: $$
243: = \int_{t_1}^{t_2} dt \int_{\mathcal{B}_t} \rho_{\text{spatial}}(x) \sqrt{\det g(x)} \, dx
244: $$
245: 
246: where $\mathcal{B}_t = \{x : d_{\mathcal{X}}(x_1, x) < c(t - t_1) \text{ and } d_{\mathcal{X}}(x, x_2) < c(t_2 - t)\}$ is the spatial slice at time $t$.
247: 
248: **Key observations**:
249: 1. $\mathcal{B}_t$ is a **compact subset** of $\mathcal{X}$ (bounded by two balls)
250: 2. $\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x) = (1/Z) \sqrt{\det g} e^{-U_{\text{eff}}/T}$ is **integrable** over compact sets
251: 3. The time integral is over a **finite interval** $[t_1, t_2]$
252: 
253: Therefore $\mathbb{E}[|I(e_1, e_2)|] < \infty$, and for any finite realization, $|I(e_1, e_2)| < \infty$ almost surely. ✓
254: 
255: **Conclusion**: All three axioms are satisfied, so $(E, \prec_{\text{CST}})$ is a causal set.
